### Describe the bug

The `status` search param is no longer taking effect so, say we had 10 orders and 2 of them had a 'completed' `status`. We call the api to GET orders and return those with the 'completed' `status` as follows:

```
params: {
                    status: 'completed',
                },
```
it is returning ALL orders, no matter what their status

### Expected behavior

If we had 10 orders and 2 of them had a 'completed' `status`. We call the api to GET orders and return those with the 'completed' `status` as follows:

```
params: {
                    status: 'completed',
                },
```

We would expect the 2 orders with the completed status to be returned

### Actual behavior

If we have 10 orders and 2 of them had a 'completed' `status`. We call the api to GET orders and return those with the 'completed' `status` as follows:

```
params: {
                    status: 'completed',
                },
```
it is returning ALL orders, no matter what their status

### Steps to reproduce

1. Enable COT/HPOS
2. Use the WooCommerce API to create 8 orders, 2 with status completed
3. Attempt to search on orders and return those with 'completed' status with search param as follows:
{
        status: 'completed'
}
4. All orders are returned



###

### Describe the bug

The `page` search param is no longer taking effect so, say we had 10 orders and we called the api to GET orders and return the first page using search params as follows:
```
params: {
                    per_page: 4,
                    page: 1
},
```

it is returning the same results as below:

```
params: {
                    per_page: 4,
                    page: 2
},
```
 i.e. both only returning the first page values

### Expected behavior

The `page` search param should have an effect on the results returned in the GET orders call

i.e. If we had 10 orders and we called the api to GET orders and return the first page using search params as follows:
```
params: {
                    per_page: 4,
                    page: 1
},
```

It should returning different results to below:

```
params: {
                    per_page: 4,
                    page: 2
},
```
 i.e. the first call should return the first 4 orders and the second call should return the next 4 (different) orders

### Actual behavior

The `page` search param is no longer taking effect so, say we had 10 orders and we called the api to GET orders and return the first page using search params as follows:
```
params: {
                    per_page: 4,
                    page: 1
},
```

it is returning the same results as below:

```
params: {
                    per_page: 4,
                    page: 2
},
```
 i.e. both only returning the first page values

### Steps to reproduce

1. Enable COT/HPOS
2. Use the WooCommerce API to create 8 orders
3. Attempt to search on orders and get the first page of results (given 4 results per page) with search param as follows:
```
{
                    per_page: 4,
                    page: 1
}
```
4. Attempt to search on orders and get the second page of results (given 4 results per page) with search param as follows:
```
{
                    per_page: 4,
                    page: 2
}
```
5. The same results are returned for each

**Description:** we show up to 25 notifications on the Inbox panel. This volume of messages makes it difficult to parse all the information and we don't offer an easy way to see older messages. The users need to delete messages to see older messages, which is a poor user experience.

- [x] Display the 5 most recent messages with a "Show older" CTA at the bottom of the panel
- [x] Load 10 messages when the user clicks "Show older" and change the CTA copy to "Show more"
- [x] The "Show more" CTA always loads the next 10 messages and it's displayed at the bottom until all messages are loaded

**Description:** At the moment, a high percentage of users have reached the limit of the number of messages shown on the panel (25). This creates an overwhelming experience, making it difficult to parse all the information and distinguish new messages from older content. This epic will include a number of low-effort improvements to increase the visibility of new messages.

The "Product short description" field (both visual and text editor) fails to save or update in 7.0 Beta/RC. I can confirm this works in 6.9.4

### Expected behavior

On adding a new product or updating existing product information in "Product short description" field should be saved

### Actual behavior

On adding a new product or updating existing product information in "Product short description" field fails to save.

### Steps to reproduce

1. In wp-admin Add New Product (or open existing product)
2. Enter information into "Product short description" 
3. Save/Update
4. See information wasn't saved



###

:**
Vendor/Partner request: Our Bulk Table Editor uses date + time to schedule sales. Customers is complaining about the sale is not ending. We did some research and found that the cron job for sales ( wc_scheduled_sales ) just runs once a day. So having a sale from 09:00 to 12:00 the same day (or the like) is not possible anymore. This used to work. We manually changed this cron job to run every minute and problem solved. I think many WooCommerce users think that once a day is OK but if you schedule a sale using time it will not do. So our suggestion is: 1. In WooCommerce settings make an option to change this cron job. 2. Make a hook (filter) so developers can change the sales cron job (recurrence). Thanks, Tommy Hansen - Consortia AS

### Describe the bug

If any meta value that is going to be printed in the "Custom Fields" section of an order screen (/wp-admin/admin.php?page=wc-orders&id=(ID)&action=edit) is not a string, then a TypeError exception (and crash, being uncaught) will occur because the variable is passed to `htmlspecialchars()` as-is, without having been turned back to a string.

N.B. https://woocommerce.github.io/code-reference/classes/WC-Data.html#method_update_meta_data shows that it is valid to store non-strings as meta-values.

### Actual behavior

```
PHP Fatal error:  Uncaught TypeError: htmlspecialchars(): Argument #1 ($string) must be of type string, stdClass given in wp-includes/formatting.php:4604
Stack trace:
#0 wp-includes/formatting.php(4604): htmlspecialchars()
#1 wp-admin/includes/template.php(643): esc_textarea()
#2 wp-admin/includes/template.php(600): _list_meta_row()
#3 wp-content/plugins/woocommerce/src/Internal/Admin/Orders/MetaBoxes/CustomMetaBox.php(74): list_meta()
#4 wp-content/plugins/woocommerce/src/Internal/Admin/Orders/MetaBoxes/CustomMetaBox.php(60): Automattic\WooCommerce\Internal\Admin\Orders\MetaBoxes\CustomMetaBox->render_custom_meta_form()
#5 wp-content/plugins/woocommerce/src/Internal/Admin/Orders/Edit.php(172): Automattic\WooCommerce\Internal\Admin\Orders\MetaBoxes\CustomMetaBox->output()
#6 wp-admin/includes/template.php(1402): Automattic\WooCommerce\Internal\Admin\Orders\Edit->render_custom_meta_box()
#7 wp-content/plugins/woocommerce/src/Internal/Admin/Orders/Edit.php(251): do_meta_boxes()
#8 wp-content/plugins/woocommerce/src/Internal/Admin/Orders/Edit.php(180): Automattic\WooCommerce\Internal\Admin\Orders\Edit->render_meta_boxes()
#9 wp-content/plugins/woocommerce/src/Internal/Admin/Orders/PageController.php(163): Automattic\WooCommerce\Internal\Admin\Orders\Edit->display()
#10 wp-includes/class-wp-hook.php(307): Automattic\WooCommerce\Internal\Admin\Orders\PageController->output()
#11 wp-includes/class-wp-hook.php(331): WP_Hook->apply_filters()
#12 wp-includes/plugin.php(476): WP_Hook->do_action()
#13 wp-admin/admin.php(259): do_action()
#14 {main}
  thrown in wp-includes/formatting.php on line 4604
```

### Steps to reproduce

In this example, order ID 1234 is an existing order.

```
# php80 -a
> require 'wp-load.php';
> $order = wc_get_order(1234); // Some existing order
> $thing = new stdClass;
> $thing->value = 'anything';
> $order->update_meta_data('any_key', $thing);
> $order->save();
> exit;
```

Then visit the order page - /wp-admin/admin.php?page=wc-orders&id=1234&action=edit

This issue tracks rendering column values via action so that extensibility parity is maintained with the posts list.

"date_completed_gmt": null

When the HPOS data-store is in use, a newly created order may be stored with the wrong creation date: this should be GMT, but it seems possible for it to be stored in whatever the WP timezone is. ### Steps to replicate 1. Enable COT/HPOS. 2. Via **Settings ▸ General** set your WP timezone to `America/Vancouver` or some other non-GMT timezone. 3. As a customer, create a new order. 4. As an admin user, promptly visit **WooCommerce ▸ Orders** and look at the new entry in the list table. In the date column, we could reasonably expect to see something like *"Created 10 seconds ago"* but in fact we will see a displacement such as *"Created 7 hours ago"* (if you were to select `America/Vancouver`, at least): 6. Similarly, if you inspect the corresponding row of the `wp_wc_orders` table, you will see the entry in the `date_created_gmt` column is close to the current time as per the WP timezone setting. ###

Make it possible to check if COT is in use via the System Status Report. ☝🏽 Perhaps something like this mock, though it's just an idea. Perhaps it would make more sense to specify the data-store class (which would also surface custom data-stores). ###

_This task is framed in the context of the COT/HPOS project but the implementation will be useful for any future new feature as well_

After https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/pull/34727 is merged we need to do something when there are plugins that are incompatible with one or more of the existing features.

To start with, we decide that a given plugin is incompatible with a given feature if either:

1. It explicitly declares incompatibility with the feature using the `FeaturesController` class introduced in the mentioned pull request; or
2. It has a `WC tested up to` header but does _not_ declare compatibility with the feature.

Now, the "something" to do is:

1. In the WordPress plugins page, show a warning under the plugin name, indicating that the plugin is incompatible with one or more features. Similar to this, but the message will be more like "Incompatible with X existing features, click here to manage WooCommerce features"

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/937723/192739534-4ea573f4-c7a5-4745-a00d-6fa72f15745f.png)

2. Additionally, if at least one of the features is enabled, it won't be possible to activate the plugin:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/937723/192740050-6e96fc99-3d51-47f1-86f9-40e1b9a882fd.png)

3. Disallow enabling a feature if at least one incompatible plugin is active.

4. Under each disabled feature show a warning with the count of incompatible plugins, together with a link to a list of the plugins that are incompatible with the feature.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/937723/192745051-93d642f6-fd29-43b7-823d-16f8f64fdb11.png)

6. The list of plugins incompatible with a given feature will be implemented as a new section in the WordPress plugins page, the section will only be visible when accessed via the said link:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/937723/192742540-dd79007d-04c1-4338-895d-b1c5aa8993ba.png)

cc @jarekmorawski

### Prerequisites

- [X] I have carried out troubleshooting steps and I believe I have found a bug.
- [X] I have searched for similar bugs in both open and closed issues and cannot find a duplicate.

### Describe the bug

In WooCommerce Payments, we display a task list in Payments > Overview, using [`CollapsibleList`](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/blob/trunk/packages/js/experimental/src/experimental-list/collapsible-list/index.tsx) and [`TaskItem`](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/blob/trunk/packages/js/experimental/src/experimental-list/task-item/index.tsx) from '@woocommerce/experimental' (see [here](https://github.com/Automattic/woocommerce-payments/blob/0b2030b7a99210461f5a3a35b97f9400a3a1654c/client/overview/task-list/index.js#L177-L219));

We noticed that the dismiss action from the ellipses menu gets cut off when we open it. The text is not readable and it's impossible to dismiss the task (see the issue raised: https://github.com/Automattic/woocommerce-payments/issues/4470).
This is only happening when the Gutenberg plugin is also installed. Gutenberg comes with `@wordpress/components` v20.0.0 and WooCommerce Payments bundles v11.1.5, so once Gutenberg is installed, the site is using v20.0.0.

![Screen Recording 7-21-2022 at 8 45 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5121465/180345688-ef7d402b-499e-4ee1-a438-9a727309f0e8.gif)

The same behavior can be observed in the TaskList StoryBook: https://woocommerce.github.io/woocommerce-admin/components/storybook/?path=/story/woocommerce-admin-experimental-list--task-item-example

It looks like this is due to a change in how the ellipsis menu is built in `@wordpress/components`. There used to be a `position: fixed` on one of the `<div>` from the ellipsis menu (v11.1.5), and I can see now that it uses `position: absolute`. 
And the TaskItem defines a class with an `overflow: hidden` rule (see [here](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/blob/ea6a0d31f999a60f99b3625071b860476255629a/plugins/woocommerce-admin/client/tasks/task-list.scss#L2)), which now affects the absolute positioned div from the menu (while it had no effects on it when it was fixed).

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28830738/191742281-e796e546-5ce6-4e8f-a271-201730f20c67.png)

We may just need to remove the `position: relative` on `woocommerce-experimental-list__item` and move it one level up, to avoid having the absolute div relatively positioned to the element with hidden overflow.

### Expected behavior

When clicking on the ellipsis menu from a task, we can see the content and dismiss the task.

### Actual behavior

When clicking on the ellipsis menu from a task, we cannot see the content and dismiss the task.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Go to https://woocommerce.github.io/woocommerce-admin/components/storybook/?path=/story/woocommerce-admin-experimental-list--task-item-example
2. Click on the ellipsis menu and observe that the content cannot be seen properly

###

Currently our automated workflow is to add milestones to PRs when it also contains the label `plugins: woocommerce`. However this can sometimes be missed if the PR does not contain this label and gets merged [for example](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/pull/34382). 

The [workflow](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/blob/trunk/.github/workflows/pull-request-post-merge-processing.yml) had an initial acceptance criteria set [here](36-gh-woocommerce/platform-private). I believe it was so that other items in the monorepo such as tools does not get picked up as a release PR.

The better solution "if possible" perhaps is to exclude the paths that are not going into WooCommerce release. For example https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/tree/trunk/tools

Acceptance criteria:
* Add milestone to PRs only if the PR contains work that goes into the WooCommerce release.

### Describe the bug

The bug is present in WooCommerce `trunk` as of the time of writing this (it's not present in the latest released version, 6.9.3)

It's not possible to generate an API key through the WooCommerce - Settings - Advanced - REST API - Add key button (URL: `/wp-admin/admin.php?page=wc-settings&tab=advanced&section=keys&create-key=1`), the screen keeps showing a progress indicator forever and the network inspeactor shows that the `POST /wp-admin/admin-ajax.php` request (action: `woocommerce_update_api_key`) has resulted in a 500 error.

The error is thrown in the backend by `WCAdminAssets::get_script_asset_filename` while trying to resolve the path for the file `assets/client/admin/wp-admin-scripts/payment-method-promotions`. The `assets/client/admin` folder exists but it's empty.

This is also causing the E2E tests to fail, since as part of the tests setup a key is created using the said settings page.

### Expected behavior

The requested file exists and the error doesn't appear, the key creation succeeds and so do the E2E tests.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Start with a fresh clone of the WooCommerce repository in `trunk`
2. `pnpm install`, then `pnpm run build`
3. Notice how `plugins/woocommerce/assets/client/admin` folder exists and is empty
4. Try to create a REST API key by going to Settings - Advanced - REST API - Add key and see the described behavior

Possibly related: `pnpm run build` does actually succeed for 22 tasks and fails for the last one:

> ERROR in client/tasks/fills/tax/woocommerce-tax/plugins.tsx:77:5
woocommerce/client/admin:turbo:build: TS2322: Type '{ onComplete: (activatedPlugins: string[], response: InstallPluginsResponse) => void; onError: (errors: unknown, response: unknown) => void; onSkip: () => void; skipText: string; onAbort: () => void; abortText: string; }' is not assignable to type 'IntrinsicAttributes & { children?: ReactNode; }'.

In WooCommerce 6.9.3 22 tasks succeed and none fails.

### Describe the bug

Somehow, our database eventually holds related-products transients that are not arrays. In this case, we are experiencing warnings on the site.
I think the code should just check for the validity of the data recovered from the transients in the database.

### Expected behavior

If the code finds a related-product transients that are not the expected array then it should simply consider them invalid and recalculate them, overwriting the invalid transient in the database.

### Actual behavior

The current code, when finds a related-products transient that is not an array, recalculates the correct list of related products but then emits a warning while trying to save them, not being able to do it.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Force a wrong string value for the related-products transient for a given product_id. For example, for the product with ID 470242 the transient name would be `wc_related_4270242`.
2. Force a call of the function wc_get_related_products() with that same product id. You should get a warning message, as you will be trying to access the string as an array.

### Prerequisites

- [X] I have searched for similar bugs in both open and closed issues and cannot find a duplicate.

### Describe the bug

When using the php 8.0 apache module I get this error in woo:
`PHP Fatal error:  Only variables can be passed by reference in /htdocs/wp-content/plugins/woocommerce/includes/class-wc-download-handler.php on line 559`
It seems php 8.0 does not allow dereferencing of numbers. The manual seems quite clear on this:
https://www.php.net/manual/en/language.references.pass.php

If I switch to php8.0-fpm the error does not occur. The problem also doesn't occur with the php 7.4 module.

I think the line
`if ( function_exists( 'apache_setenv' ) ) {`
returns false under php-fpm which is why we only get the problem when using the module.
This change to the woo code works here:

From
```
if ( function_exists( 'apache_setenv' ) ) {
                        @apache_setenv( 'no-gzip', 1 ); // phpcs:ignore Generic.PHP.NoSilencedErrors.Discouraged, WordPress.PHP.DiscouragedPHPFunctions.runtime_configuration_apache_setenv
                }
```
To:
```
if ( function_exists( 'apache_setenv' ) ) {
                        $one    = 1;
                        @apache_setenv( 'no-gzip', $one ); // phpcs:ignore Generic.PHP.NoSilencedErrors.Discouraged, WordPress.PHP.DiscouragedPHPFunctions.runtime_configuration_apache_setenv
                }
```
We are on Debian 10.



### Expected behavior

Viewing the homepage should be possible.  A fatal error should not occur.

### Actual behavior

Homepage is not rendered, screen shows 
**There has been a critical error on this website.**

Apache error log file has fatal described above.

Email sent to site owner:
Error Details

An error of type E_COMPILE_ERROR was caused in line 559 of the file
/home/path/htdocs/wp-content/plugins/woocommerce/includes/class-wc-download-handler.php.
Error message: Only variables can be passed by reference

### Steps to reproduce

1.  Switch environment to apache's mod_php for php 8.0.

### Describe the bug When creating an order programmatically using `wc_create_order();` and subsequently re-fetching the order and tryping to obtain `customer_id` from `wp_customer_lookup` table using `$order->get_report_customer_id()` I got and SQL error: ``` Column 'first_name' cannot be null ``` Query: ``` INSERT INTO `wp_wc_customer_lookup` (`first_name`, `last_name`, `email`, `city`, `state`, `postcode`, `country`, `date_last_active`) VALUES (NULL, NULL, '', NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, '2022-09-14 15:41:31') ``` I was able to track the issue down to the [CustomerDataStorore::get_customer_order_data_and_format](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/blob/a49f23abfde57fbd7989ba2ea7b769998876d6b3/plugins/woocommerce/src/Admin/API/Reports/Customers/DataStore.php#L542-L578) method where when COT is enabled the data containg NULLs instead of empty strings. Another difference I noticed was that order created via admin UI has rows in `wp_wc_order_addresses` but the order created programmatically has not. This would explain the NULL values. E.g. `$order->get_billing_city( 'edit' )` returns `null` but I believe that expected value is an empty string. I tested the issue with the [COT Release testing build](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/releases/tag/feature-custom-order-table) and also with a build I made from recent `cot-main` branch ([commit](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/commit/a49f23abfde57fbd7989ba2ea7b769998876d6b3)). ### Expected behavior No SQL error and `$order->get_report_customer_id()` should create a new row in `wp_customer_lookup` in case there isn't any for the order. ### Actual behavior An SQL error: Column 'first_name' cannot be null ### Steps to reproduce I created a plugin that can be used for replication of the issue. [woo_cot_error.php.zip](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/files/9567253/woo_cot_error.php.zip) This is what the plugin does: ```php $cotEnabled = get_option(\Automattic\WooCommerce\Internal\DataStores\Orders\CustomOrdersTableController::CUSTOM_ORDERS_TABLE_USAGE_ENABLED_OPTION); echo "COT enabled: $cotEnabled
"; $order = wc_create_order(); echo "Order id: {$order->get_id()}
"; $order = wc_get_order($order->get_id()); $city = $order->get_billing_city( 'edit' ); $cityVal = var_export($city, true); $cityValExpected = var_export("", true); echo "Expected output of \$order->get_billing_city( 'edit' );: $cityValExpected
"; echo "Output of \$order->get_billing_city( 'edit' );: $cityVal
"; $order->get_report_customer_id(); ``` 1. Install WooCommerce version with COT and enable COT 2. Install the plugin 3. Click "Woo COT error" in admin sidebar 4. Observe the issue: I was able to replicate the issue on my local dev site and also on wp.com dev site. Locally I tested the issue on PHP 8.0 with MariaDB 10.5.8 and also MySQL 8.0. ###

This is related to the epic issue https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/issues/33895. When users use the current release of WooCommerce plugins (without the UI revamp for marketing page feature), the recommended extensions would come from calling `GET https://woocommerce.com/wp-json/wccom/marketing-tab/1.1/recommendations.json` API. https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/blob/996e56898704fafbb4cba4e566f82f3716276cf2/plugins/woocommerce/src/Internal/Admin/Marketing.php#L194-L215 The API response will be stored in the `RECOMMENDED_PLUGINS_TRANSIENT = 'wc_marketing_recommended_plugins'`, for a duration of 3 days. When users update the WooCommerce plugin with the UI revamp for marketing page feature, the recommended extensions should come from calling `GET https://woocommerce.com/wp-json/wccom/marketing-tab/1.2/recommendations.json` API. Note that the version is changed from "1.1" to "1.2" in the URL. However, because we have the data from version 1.1 still cached in the transient, the above API version 1.2 won't be called until the transient is expired or deleted. When users view the normal Marketing page, there won't be an issue. However, when users enable the multichannel marketing feature in WC Settings and view the new beta multichannel Marketing page, there will be a UI error, because the page is expecting data from version 1.2, but it receives data from version 1.1 cached in the transient: ## Possible solutions I can think of two solutions. Solution 1: We delete the transient when users enable / disable the multichannel marketing feature in WC Settings. I think this may be done in https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/blob/cf25f5d9961955bb4f2d787fa5cd6b6bbb083550/plugins/woocommerce/src/Admin/Features/MultichannelMarketing/Init.php. Solution 2: We delete the transient when users update the WooCommerce plugin. See https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/blob/996e56898704fafbb4cba4e566f82f3716276cf2/plugins/woocommerce/includes/wc-update-functions.php for some prior art examples. I think this may be the better solution. The code for this work should be based on the [`feature/33895-marketing-page/main`](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/tree/feature/33895-marketing-page/main) branch, or the `trunk` branch after PR https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/pull/34642 is merged. ###

We have a workflow to deal with enhancement requests by way of voting.

https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/blob/6.8.2/.github/workflows/triage-replies.yml#L86-L120

Once the label is applied, the issue is closed and voting can begin. There are a few problems:

* Voting on a closed issue seems like a wasted democratic effort
* Issues to be voted on aren't easily found because they are closed
* Even if they are found, one might not partake in the democratic process due to thinking its not relevant anymore
* The comment doesn't say how to vote
* We are not getting an accurate measure of how much demand there might be for issues

This issue should investigate an alternate solution. Perhaps like closing an issue if not enough votes are gathered in a set time period?

## Add permalink template read only property to Product REST api

### Description

We currently have to retrieve the `permalink_template` and `generated_slug` separately from the WP posts endpoint in order to show a permalink for draft products. This is causing an unnecessary extra delay when loading products.

We should add the `permalink_template` and `generated_slug` properties as readonly fields to the Products REST api.
We can use the same logic as what Wordpress uses for the posts endpoint -> https://github.com/WordPress/WordPress/blob/master/wp-includes/rest-api/endpoints/class-wp-rest-posts-controller.php#L1950-L1964

A `getPermalinkParts` selector has already been added to the products data store and can be re-used once we updated the products REST api endpoint to use that instead ( this was added as part of https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/pull/34313 ).

This task will include:
- The addition of two readonly fields as part of the products REST api ( https://woocommerce.github.io/woocommerce-rest-api-docs/#retrieve-a-product )
- Updating the `getPermalinkParts` selector to make use of the products REST api data store instead of the posts data store.

Design:
5sAIeTRd9Yp7nSCT33BAWz-fi-6135%3A243581

Some extra context in this Slack thread, including an idea to add it as a readonly field instead: p1660331212163919-slack-C0E1AV8T0

### Describe the bug

This bug was found in https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce-min-max-quantities/issues/176 and is reported here as a core issue.

The quantity input box is not shown when a product's min qty and max qty are the same. The code responsible for this can be found [here](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/blob/trunk/plugins/woocommerce/templates/global/quantity-input.php#L20-L25). I think the reasoning behind it could be that if the user cannot set the quantity of the product anyways, then what's the point of showing input box. 

However, this creates an issue that the user does not know what the quantity is, so IMO it's better if the quantity input is disabled when `min_qty=max_qty`.

### Expected behaviour

Input quantity is shown when min_qty=max_qty

### Actual behavior

Input quantity is not shown when min_qty=max_qty

### Steps to reproduce

1. Add https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce-min-max-quantities/ plugin.
2. Create a simple product with min_qty=max_qty=5
3. Add product to the cart.

You will see that the qty input box is no longer visible. If you change the min qty to 4, you'll be able to see the quantity input box.

We currently have an automated cherry picking tool. While it work as expected, there are edge cases where it will fail. This issue is to track what issues we see happening and address it.

* If the readme.txt has no changelog entries (ref: https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/blob/trunk/plugins/woocommerce/readme.txt ), the step that adds the changelog entry will not add anything because it expects some changelog entries to be there already so it knows where to insert the changelog entry.
* This closely relates to the first issue and perhaps are related and fixing this one will actually fix both. The issue is if the changelog entry `Type` does not already exist in the readme.txt changelog entries, then it will also not add it because it doesn't know where to append that entry.

So I think to fix the issues, we need to add the changelog entry even if there are no existing entries and second, add the changelog entry to the end of the list if the changelog entry `Type` does not already exist.

Here is the cherry pick tools we need to potentially fix:
https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/blob/trunk/.github/workflows/cherry-pick.yml

### Actual behavior

It returns the currency sign: 'kr'.

Set up a site to use the danish currency and see.

We use `DataSourcePoller` to fetch remote data from WCCOM, but it doesn't support the i18n feature. 

To add the i18n support, we need to

1. Send a request to WCCOM endpoint with locale- `https://woocommerce.com/wp-json/wccom/my-endpoint?locale=zh_TW`
2. Locale is stored in database in associative array `array( 'en_US' => ...., 'zh_TW => ... )`
3. DataSourcePoller.php includes your filter logic to retrieve the correct locale based on site/user.






###

Particularly for the orders and products API endpoints, the objects in the response include a `meta_data` property which is an array of key/value pairs, representing postmeta. This array can be quite large in some cases, which can significantly increase the size of the response payload. The mobile apps only need a few specific meta keys, so I'm proposing that we add two new collection parameters for orders and products:

* `include_meta` would work similarly to `_fields` but only for meta keys. Only the keys specified would be retrieved and included in the response.
* `exclude_meta` would do the opposite, retrieving and including all meta keys except the ones specified.

In the case where both parameters are used in one request, I think `include_meta` would take precedence, since it would usually be more specific.

### Describe the bug

A client has told us that some people, after entering their data in the checkout form and indicating the payment method, get an error. An exclamation appears as if some data was missing in the form, but without a message.
![exclamation error](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/109524914/179711226-a6584d3f-667b-4d56-a8e5-cbb910b55dcd.png)


We have tried to reproduce the error, but it works fine for us. Apparently it only happens to some people. We have deduced that it could be that something on the user's computer is blocking the payment, but we don't know for sure.

Do you have any idea what could be causing this error?

### Expected behavior

The client fills in the form, selects the payment method and when clicking on "Place order" or "Go to Paypal" the web redirects him to the corresponding page.

### Actual behavior

Some customers fill out the form, select the payment method and when they click "Place order" or "Go to Paypal" an error appears in the form of an exclamation mark (as if something on the form is wrong), but without any message indicating that error is about.

### Steps to reproduce

1. The customer selects a product and it is sent to the shopping cart.
2. The customer accesses the shopping cart, clicks "Checkout" and is sent to the checkout page.
3. A form appears on the checkout page, the customer fills it out, selects the payment method and when clicking on "Place order" the aforementioned error appears.

### Describe the bug

If I start working through the WooCommerce Onboarding tasks and choose the "Create a custom homepage" option. The page is created. However, there is a Cover block at the top, which has an orphaned Button block within it. It appears that the Button block is set to align center. However, since it is not wrapped within a Buttons block it is not centered and floats to the left. This is older Gutenberg behavior and the markup that is output should contain a Buttons block with a nested Button block.

I'm currently running the latest from `trunk` of WooCommerce, but I've also tested this on an InstaWP site with WooCommerce installed and Storefront theme. 

**Note:** this issue does **_not happen with Storefront theme_**, because Storefront is accounting for older Gutenberg behavior and has special CSS targeting this scenario. However, the Button block _should_ be wrapped within a Buttons block and not have special CSS to account for it.

However, this should be addressed to allow for Full Site Editing themes (aka block themes) to not have to have extra CSS to account for older (deprecated) Gutenberg markup.

![Screen Shot 2022-07-15 at 11 12 12 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/405912/179252823-9ed1f061-a7b8-471e-8857-5ab0dd7c87ab.png)

I'm not certain where the markup is coming from to populate the custom homepage. I would assume it is coming from the WooCommerce onboarding code, but if this is entirely a Storefront issue then I'm happy to log an Issue there. Thanks!

cc: @Aljullu

### Expected behavior

The Button block within the Cover block should be wrapped within a Buttons block and centered.

2. Go to /wp-admin/admin.php?page=wc-admin to visit the Onboarding tasks, and choose the "Personalize my store" and "Create a custom homepage"
3. Once the homepage is created and set. Visit your site's homepage and verify that the first button on the page is floated to the left, as opposed to the center.

![Screen Shot 2022-07-14 at 6 10 19 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/405912/179250533-36bf1a4a-7991-4ff5-b8ec-8b245c4e970f.png)

:**

The entire point of using Turborepo is to take advantage of task caching. We need to integrate this caching into our CI so that we can speed it up.

* Use a branch-specific cache key
* Cache `.turbo` directories in each package, likely using our composite install/build action
  * We can take this opportunity to make sure all of the workflows are using this too!

###

:**

We are currently requiring contributors to use both `pnpm` and `turbo` commands. This has proven unwieldy for many people, so, I'd like to iterate on our current usage of Turborepo.

* Change pipelines to `turbo:` prefixed ones.
* Move `build`, `lint`, `test`, and `e2e` scripts into `turbo:` prefixed ones.
* Replace `build`, `lint`, `test,` and `e2e` scripts with those that run `turbo` commands.
  * We need to make sure arguments are passed correctly to both turbo _and_ the underlying script.
  * These should use `--filter` and either the project name or the `package.json`'s directory (maybe there's an `$npm_` variable to get this information?. This way they're only running on the project.
* Add root `build`, `lint`, `test,` and `e2e` scripts that run `turbo` commands without a `--filter`.
* Replace `pnpm -- turbo run` documentation with this easier-to-follow documentation. We _do_ want to keep Turborepo extensively documented in some form so that people are aware of the more complex usage, but, it should be for advanced users.
* Aggressively communicate this to developers internally.

Our goal with this work is to make it so that you can run `pnpm build|lint|test|e2e` commands from within a package folder without knowing anything about Turborepo. It will still be available (and documented) for those who want to use more powerful commands, but, this should cover most use-cases.

**Issue Description:**

The generation of the changelog automatically on release seems to have failed while attempting to remove the change files. See [this run](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/actions/runs/2671701840).

That issue needs to be fixed, and it'd be ideal if the release changelog generation could be run separate from the rest of the code freeze code, so that if it failed, it doesn't affect the notification.

###

Invalid change file affect some of the automations that we've put in place tied to the release and create more manual work in the process of creating the release. We should add a pre-push hook that validates both that a change file is present in a PR (if required), and that the change file is valid.

This is part of the epic issue https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/issues/33895. In this issue, we want to implement a feature toggle that allows users to switch between the old UI and the new UI: - When the toggle is on, `/wp-admin/admin.php?page=wc-admin&path=%2Fmarketing` will display the new UI. - For starter, the new UI can be just an empty placeholder page. We will put in components into the page in other tasks. - When the toggle is off, `/wp-admin/admin.php?page=wc-admin&path=%2Fmarketing` will display the existing UI. The toggle can be put into the WooCommerce > Settings > Advanced > Features page: `/wp-admin/admin.php?page=wc-settings&tab=advanced§ion=features` ###

### Describe the bug

After creating a new product via API (successful) trying to update that same product later with more and other details but still the same SKU, it returns an error as below. 
I'm not creating a new product, I'm just updating the existing product with the same SKU. 

{"code":"product_invalid_sku","message":"Ongeldig of dubbel artikelnummer.","data":{"status":400,"resource_id":361069}}

I can't remember this behavior was like this before. Did something change in one of the last WooCommerce updates that is causing this behavior? 

### Expected behavior

Just update the existing product with the same SKU instead of throwing an error. 

### Actual behavior

I create a new product via API, example SKU "SKU1" with some meta data for title and description. 
It returns ID example 1234

After this process I want to update the product with ID 1234 and pass meta data for price and category and the same SKU "SKU1". 
API returns an error {"code":"product_invalid_sku","message":"Ongeldig of dubbel artikelnummer.","data":{"status":400,"resource_id":1234}}

So this results in impossible to update the price or any other fields because the SKU is "the same"? 
When I remove the SKU field from the PUT body, it works fine. 
If I put a DIFFERENT SKU via PUT body, it also works fine!

So clearly there is something off going on that does not accept the same SKU for the same product ID it already has. 

### Steps to reproduce

1. create a new product via API, example SKU "SKU1" with some meta data for title and description. 
2. It returns ID example 1234

3. update the product with ID 1234 and pass meta data for price and category and the same SKU "SKU1". 
4. API returns an error {"code":"product_invalid_sku","message":"Ongeldig of dubbel artikelnummer.","data":{"status":400,"resource_id":1234}}

### Describe the bug

I used to be able to query WC attribute terms in the block editor, but it's apparently it's not possible anymore.

It works for `product_cat` and `product_tag` though with the steps below (actually now there's no need to expose them to the api anymore)

### Expected behavior

Expose the attribute to the rest API

```
$pa_my_attribute                          = get_taxonomy( 'pa_my_attribute');
$pa_my_attribute->show_in_rest  = true;
```

And then access the terms in the block editor:

```
taxTerms: select( 'core' ).getEntityRecords( 'taxonomy', 'pa_my_attribute' , queryParams )
```

### Actual behavior

Instead of loading a list of terms I get a console error:

`GET http://shop.lovelanghe.test/wp-json/false/pa_denomination?context=edit&per_page=100&_locale=user 404 (Not Found)`

### Steps to reproduce

expose an attribute to the API
```
$pa_your_attribute                          = get_taxonomy( 'pa_your_attribute');
$pa_your_attribute ->show_in_rest  = true;
```

And then try to query its terms in the block editor

```
taxTerms: select( 'core' ).getEntityRecords( 'taxonomy', 'pa_your_attribute ' , queryParams )
```

###

Order types can be registered via `wc_register_order_type()` and are also propagated to WP as post types. We do this for refunds, but also 3rd party extensions (Subscriptions, for example) use it to register their own order types.

We currently have no way to store this information in the COT tables.

This issue's scope includes including the field in the schema, updating the migration to move this data, adding support for the `type` query var in `WC_Order_Query`, etc.

### Describe the bug

It seems there are some gaps in the logic we used to manage default shipping zones and shipping task.

An example case would be a user from US who already has Jetpack installed but doesn't have WCS, they would not be able to see the shipping task, nor have the default shipping zones created. 

- The check for shipping task to appear [doesn't include US](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/blob/b274831334fe8979ad7eaa4db579b030a7451019/plugins/woocommerce/src/Admin/Features/OnboardingTasks/Tasks/Shipping.php#L113)
- The [check for creating]( https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/blob/trunk/plugins/woocommerce/src/Internal/Admin/Homescreen.php#L118:L122) shipping zones does not cover users who has Jetpack installed but not installed WCS

### Expected behavior

Ideally, I think we should have the logic consolidated where there will never be a case for users to neither have the shipping task visible nor shipping zones created. However, if this is too complicated, we should just fix the case mentioned above.

### Actual behavior

Edge case happens for some users

### Steps to reproduce

 1. Create a fresh site in the US, select physical products, install Jetpack in extension step
2. Observe no shipping task nor review shipping options in setup tasklist
3. Observe no shipping zones set

### Isolating the problem

- [X] I have deactivated other plugins and confirmed this bug occurs when only WooCommerce plugin is active.
- [X] This bug happens with a default WordPress theme active, or [Storefront](https://woocommerce.com/storefront/).
- [X] I can reproduce this bug consistently using the steps above.

### Describe the bug

If we name our theme with a name containing `-` (e.g. main-theme), then woocommerce does not read all templates from the / templates folder. This behaves randomly and only reads certain files (usually from the main folder).

### Expected behavior

Reading full template from `woocommerce` folder.

### Actual behavior

Some of files (e.g. /cart/cart.php) does not work even if we delete context in files.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a theme called `main-theme`
2. Copy the /templates folder from woocommerce plugin then put it into your theme
3. Try change something and check if it's changed on site (e.g. /cart/cart.php)

**Description:** it's difficult to understand which fields or sections are being added or removed from the post data widget, as there's no indication of what happens when, for example, the user changes the product type from simple to grouped product. 

**Acceptance criteria:**

- [ ] When new product elements appear, for example for downloadable or external products, show a spotlight to point people to the place where they'll find new options


###

**Description:** during the usability walkthrough we identified that it could be challenging to find the right place to add product images or create a gallery. This can be influenced by the fact that the image & gallery widgets are buried below widgets such as Categories, Tags, Google Listing & Ads (if the extension is installed). 

**Acceptance criteria:**

- [ ] Place the product image and product gallery widgets below the publish widget

###

**Description:** the product image or gallery is one of the most impactful elements of the product page. However, we don't offer any guidance on the right image size and formats to ensure that the products have compelling images.

**Acceptance criteria:**

- [ ] Update the upload modal for "Set product image" and "Add gallery images" using the [`post-upload-ui`](https://developer.wordpress.org/reference/hooks/post-upload-ui/) hook to add specific copy (TODO) about suggestion image dimensions and format, along with a link to the WooCommerce blog article about creating great product images (TODO: include link)

**Description:** some of the copy in the Inventory section is confusing and can be easily improved

**Acceptance criteria:**

- [ ] To focus on the final result, rename “Enable stock management at product level” to “Manage stock level (quantity)” 
- [ ] Change “Enable this to only allow one of this item to be bought in a single order” to “Limit purchases to 1 item per order”
- [ ] Add a tooltip to the "Limit purchases to 1 item..." checkbox with the following copy: "Check to let customers to purchase only 1 item in a single order. This is particularly useful for items that have limited quantity, for example art or handmade goods."

**Description:** most of the Variations primary and secondary actions have discoverability and accessibility issues. These issues make it difficult for users to easily create and manage variations. 

**Designs:**
`zs56kcy53K7GoGhgyjcQ2R/%5BProject%5D-fi-209%3A30408&t=Wravf3I84jXombqq-4`

**Acceptance criteria:**

- [ ] Key actions are hidden in the dropdown menu: bring out "Generate variations" (previously "Create from all attributes") and "Add manually"(previously "Add variation") into separate buttons and rename the dropdown to "Bulk actions"
- [x] Single variation controls are hidden by default: Show the actions for each variation (Move, Remove, Open) as buttons visible at all times, rather than on hover

**Description:** the "tooltip displayed alongside the default form value option is not working - Tooltip does not appear before Draft is saved **Acceptance criteria:** - [ ] Fix the tooltip appearing - [ ] Update copy: Choose a default form value if you want a certain variation already selected when a user visits the product page ###

**Description:** the UI for creating attributes is an error-prone and time-consuming experience. We should explore ways to streamline the experience with minimal effort.  

**Acceptance criteria:**

- [ ] Add a tooltip near the "custom product attribute" dropdown and "add" CTA with a link to the support doc: https://woocommerce.com/document/managing-product-taxonomies/#section-6
- [ ] If there are no attributes in the store: show the add attribute form by default
- [ ] If there's at least one attribute: add an empty state screen with a choice between adding a custom attribute or importing an existing one
- [ ] Add "Custom attribute" title to each new attribute until the user adds the attribute name
- [ ] The 2 expand/close options are confusing. Should we just keep one of them?
- [ ] Improve the visibility of the secondary actions: delete, etc. Should they be visible by default?
- [ ] Existing attribute options are always reset when added to a new product. Remember the last used settings for attributes, i.e. "Used for variations" and select all values by default so that the user doesn't have to add them manually 



###

**Description:** The product data naming is far from being self-explanatory and it can be challenging for users to understand the differences between all the product types. This is one of those cases where it's better to provide documentation to help users understand how to complete their tasks.

**Acceptance criteria:**

- [ ] Add a tooltip with a link to a help article about product types: https://woocommerce.com/document/managing-products/#product-types


###

**Description:** the "add media" and "add contact form" CTA can be misleading and make the users think that this is the path they need to take to add product images. 

**Acceptance criteria:**

- [x] Improve the CTA copy to make sure users understand that the media or form will be added to the description: "Add media to description" and "Add contact form to the description"
Or
- [ ] Change the layout to make it clear that the CTAs are part of the long description - similar to what we have for the short description

### Describe the bug

Moving or re-using an existing hook produces a diff that fails to match a regex looking for new changes. But since a change is made to a hook it thinks a description has not been made. 

https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/blob/a53b44f6ef6dea0a024c79fa7e40ba270771ed98/tools/code-analyzer/src/commands/analyzer/index.ts#L386-L393



### Expected behavior

These changes should pass

### Actual behavior

The tool believes a hook has been added without a description.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Add a hook that has been around for a while in the code with proper docBlock
2. Run the Analyzer CLI tool
3. Watch it fail



###

### Describe the solution you'd like

Hi,

There are lots of cases where a variant can have attributes that differs from the parent, but are not defining the variant. Obvious cases like UPC/EAN/GTIN etc are of course there, but these can be solved with meta data (even though it is kind of not-great for end users).

### Real life examples
**Life jackets**
Life jackets are typically sized by a interval of heights of the user - "20 - 30 kg", "25 - 40 kg". By adding `20,21,...30` to the former and `25,26,...40` on an attibute "Fits weights" to the latter we can enable a very nice filter on category pages where the customer can pick their weight and see all life jackets that fits them. Since every product has more than one value (20-30 is obviously 10 values) we can not use it for variants. 

**Bike tires**
Tires are variantized by it's dimensions (width and height). Wide tires **fits for** mountainbikes, while narrow tires **fits for** racing bikes. To allow customers to (in the category "Bike tires") filter by Suitable for (mountainbike|racing bike), we would need to assign that attribute to the variants. If we assign both values to the parent, the filter will be wrong as soon as one of the variants are out of stock (or hidden by any other setting such as visibility, unpublished etc).

I can go on forever, but I think the uses cases should be clear. Magento and most other platforms have solved this. It would make the PIM part of WooCommerce a great deal more flexible.

From a database perspective, I can not see why this should be very hard to implement. Most of the functionality is actually already there (thanks to the `wp_wc_product_attributes_lookup` table). Since the variants are in fact stored as separate products (posts) it should be fairly straight forward.

Is there a reason/decision taken why this is not possible? If not, would it be of interest if i tried to take a stab at an implementation?

Right now it's possible to run `pnpm build` for a plugin, package, or tool. This has a negative impact, however, since it bypasses the `turbo` cache and may leave dependencies unbuilt. We should look into detecting `turbo` execution and do nothing if the commands are not ran using it. The first thing that comes to mind would be looking for an environment variable and seeing if one is set. If not, perhaps we need to upstream a change to Turborepo to add one.

#### _Get_
**HTTP Request**

**Reference**

#### _List all_
**HTTP Request**
> **GET** `/wp-json/wc/v3/products/attributes`

**Properties**
| Parameter | Type | Description |
| --------- | -------- | -------- |
| `context` | string | Scope under which the request is made; determines fields present in response. Options: `view` and `edit`. Default is `view`. |

**Reference**
> https://woocommerce.github.io/woocommerce-rest-api-docs/#list-all-product-attributes

**Issue Description:**

Currently the PHP linter runs on a [pre-commit hook](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/blob/trunk/.husky/pre-commit#L4). This means if there are any linter violations, even in unrelated code in the same file, you get blocked from completing your commit. I find this disruptive when I'm "in the flow" and this has sometimes caused me to resort to committing with `--no-verify`, which is obviously not a great habit to get into. For new contributors, this can be confusing and discouraging ([example](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/issues/33135#issuecomment-1147334703)).

I would like to propose that the linter check instead happen on the pre-push hook.

* Better supports the habit of making atomic commits. Fixing linting violations can happen in a separate commit.
* Doesn't break your "flow".
* Still ensures that new linting violations aren't introduced to the codebase.

## User Story
> As a new merchant
> I want to the task list to contain prioritized tasks
> So I can focus on what's import to set up next

## Acceptance Criteria

Do not display the shipping task on the home page when:
- The store sells digital products only

When automated shipping options have been set in #33366:
- Change the name of the shipping task to `Review shipping options` and move it the `Things to do next` section.

Otherwise, display the `"Set up shipping"` task in the `"Get ready to start selling"` section when either of the following is true:
   -  We don't know if the store sells physical products and where it's located, and ~JP is not installed~ (https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/issues/32318#issuecomment-1119395274)
   -  The store is located in the UK, Australia or Canada
